ground_truth: Constanze curtsies, and he giggles uncomfortably as Cavalieri glares at Mozart, who looks hastily away from her. She attempts to kiss the royal hand but faints instead, causing the Emperor to contemplate her prone body and step back a pace. He nods pleasantly to all and leaves the stage with his Chamberlain, while Cavalieri, with a savage look at Mozart, leaves the stage the opposite way to her dressing room, tossing her plumed head. Salieri watches as Mozart remains indecisive for a second about whether to follow the soprano or help Madame Weber, but when Constanze catches him looking at her and tries to compose herself, she seats herself at her mirror and removes her wig as Salieri looks astonished. The door opens, Constanze enters, and Mozart hurries Constanze out of the door. Cavalieri looks after them as they go, her voice breaking and rising out of control. The old man speaks passionately to the priest while the young Salieri is kneeling in desperation before the Cross, and we see Leopold kneeling now not to the Cross but to Archbishop Colloredo, sitting impassively on his throne. Leopold, a desperate, once-handsome man of sixty, now far too much the subservient courtier, expresses deepest gratitude by kissing the Archbishop's hand, who then motions Leopold to rise. The camera pulls back to reveal Leopold kneeling beside Constanze, a priest facing them, with Madame Weber, Josefa, and Sophie Weber, and a merry-looking lady in bright clothes, the Baroness, are behind them. Out of breath, the Princess nods nervously, and Salieri smiles at him, but Salieri's face falls almost imperceptibly as a servant enters, and Salieri goes into the salon. Constanze stands closely veiled, holding a portfolio stuffed with manuscripts, and Salieri enters the salon as Constanze drops him a shy curtsy and shyly unveils. He takes the portfolio and puts it on a table, indicating a dish piled high with glazed chestnuts, which he offers to her. She takes one, puts it in her mouth, and he watches carefully before taking one himself, wearing a heavy gold signet-ring. He smiles at her, and she takes another chestnut, as the old man faces the priest; close up, the manuscript is in Mozart's handwriting. The court composer, oblivious to Constanze, who sits happily chewing chestnuts with her mouth covered in sugar, walks around and around his salon, reading the pages and dropping them on the floor when finished, his face agonized and wondering, shuddering as if in a rough and tumbling sea, experiencing the point where beauty and great pain coalesce, while more pages fall than he can read, scattering across the floor in a white cascade as he circles the room.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Constanze curtsies, and he giggles awkwardly as Cavalieri glares at Mozart, who glances hastily away from her. She endeavors to kiss the regal hand but swoons instead, causing the Emperor to ponder her supine body and step back a pace. He nods amiably to all and exits the stage with his Chamberlain, while Cavalieri, with a fierce look at Mozart, exits the stage the opposite way to her dressing room, tossing her plumed head. Salieri observes as Mozart remains indecisive for a moment about whether to follow the soprano or aid Madame Weber, but when Constanze catches him gazing at her and tries to compose herself, she seats herself at her mirror and removes her wig as Salieri appears astonished. The door opens, Constanze enters, and Mozart ushers Constanze out of the door. Cavalieri gazes after them as they depart, her voice breaking and rising out of control. The old man speaks passionately to the priest while the young Salieri is kneeling in desperation before the Cross, and we witness Leopold kneeling now not to the Cross but to Archbishop Colloredo, sitting impassively on his throne. Leopold, a desperate, formerly-handsome man of sixty, now far too much the subservient courtier, conveys deepest gratitude by kissing the Archbishop's hand, who then motions Leopold to rise. The camera pulls back to reveal Leopold kneeling beside Constanze, a priest facing them, with Madame Weber, Josefa, and Sophie Weber, and a cheerful-looking lady in bright attire, the Baroness, are behind them. Breathless, the Princess nods nervously, and Salieri smiles at him, but Salieri's face falls almost imperceptibly as a servant enters, and Salieri proceeds into the salon. Constanze stands closely veiled, holding a portfolio stuffed with manuscripts, and Salieri enters the salon as Constanze drops him a shy curtsy and shyly unveils. He takes the portfolio and places it on a table, indicating a dish piled high with glazed chestnuts, which he offers to her. She takes one, puts it in her mouth, and he watches attentively before taking one himself, wearing a heavy gold signet-ring. He smiles at her, and she takes another chestnut, as the old man faces the priest; close up, the manuscript is in Mozart's handwriting. The court composer, oblivious to Constanze, who sits happily chewing chestnuts with her mouth covered in sugar, walks around and around his salon, reading the pages and dropping them on the floor when finished, his face agonized and wondering, shuddering as if in a rough and tumbling sea, experiencing the point where beauty and great pain coalesce, while more pages fall than he can read, scattering across the floor in a white cascade as he circles the room.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Constanze curtsies, and he is giggled at uncomfortably as Mozart is glared at by Cavalieri, who is looked hastily away from by him. The royal hand is attempted to be kissed by her, but instead, she faints, causing her prone body to be contemplated by the Emperor, and a step is taken back by him. Pleasantly, all are nodded at by him, and the stage is left by him with his Chamberlain, while a savage look is cast at Mozart by Cavalieri before she leaves the stage the opposite way to her dressing room, her plumed head being tossed. Mozart is watched by Salieri as he remains indecisive for a second about whether the soprano should be followed by him or help should be given to Madame Weber, but when Constanze catches him looking at her and tries to compose herself, she seats herself at her mirror and her wig is removed by her as astonishment is expressed by Salieri. The door is opened, Constanze enters, and Constanze is hurried out of the door by Mozart. As they go, Cavalieri looks after them, her voice breaking and rising out of control. The old man passionately speaks to the priest while the young Salieri is kneeling in desperation before the Cross, and Leopold is seen kneeling now not to the Cross but to Archbishop Colloredo, who sits impassively on his throne. Leopold, a desperate, once-handsome man of sixty, now far too much the subservient courtier, kisses the Archbishop's hand to express deepest gratitude, and Leopold is motioned to rise by him. The camera pulls back to reveal Leopold kneeling beside Constanze, with a priest facing them, Madame Weber, Josefa, Sophie Weber, and a merry-looking lady in bright clothes, the Baroness, behind them. Nervously, the Princess nods, and Salieri smiles at him, but Salieri's face falls almost imperceptibly as a servant enters, prompting Salieri to go into the salon. Constanze, standing closely veiled and holding a portfolio stuffed with manuscripts, enters the salon with Salieri as she drops a shy curtsy to him and shyly unveils. The portfolio is taken by him, and it is placed on a table by him, a dish piled high with glazed chestnuts being indicated to her. She takes one, puts it in her mouth, and is watched carefully by him before one is taken by him himself, a heavy gold signet-ring being worn. He smiles at her, and another chestnut is taken by her, as the old man faces the priest; close up, the manuscript is revealed to be in Mozart's handwriting. Oblivious to Constanze, who sits happily chewing chestnuts with her mouth covered in sugar, the court composer walks around and around his salon, pages being read and dropped on the floor when finished, his face agonized and wondering, shuddering as if in a rough and tumbling sea, experiencing the point where beauty and great pain coalesce, while more pages fall than can be read by him, scattering across the floor in a white cascade as the room is circled by him.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Constanze curtsies, and Cavalieri glares at Mozart, who quickly looks away. She attempts to kiss the royal hand but faints, causing the Emperor to step back, nod pleasantly, and exit with his Chamberlain. Cavalieri gives Mozart a savage look and leaves toward her dressing room, tossing her plumed head. Salieri watches as Mozart hesitates between following the soprano or helping Madame Weber. Constanze composes herself and sits at her mirror, removing her wig as Salieri looks astonished. The door opens, Constanze enters, and Mozart hurriedly escorts her out. Cavalieri's voice breaks as she watches them depart. The old man speaks passionately to a priest while young Salieri kneels before the Cross. We see Leopold kneeling not to the Cross but to Archbishop Colloredo, expressing deep gratitude by kissing the Archbishop's hand, who then motions Leopold to rise. The camera reveals Leopold beside Constanze, with a priest, Madame Weber, Josefa, Sophie Weber, and the merry Baroness behind them. Out of breath, the Princess nods nervously, and Salieri’s face falls slightly as a servant enters. Constanze, closely veiled and holding a portfolio of manuscripts, shyly curtsies as Salieri enters the salon. He places the portfolio on a table and offers her glazed chestnuts. She eats one as Salieri watches, wearing a heavy gold signet-ring. He smiles, and she takes another chestnut. The manuscript is in Mozart's handwriting. The court composer, oblivious to Constanze, chews chestnuts with sugar-covered lips, walks around his salon, reading and dropping pages, his face agonized as beauty and pain coalesce. Pages scatter across the floor as he circles the room.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Constanze curtsies, and Cavalieri glares at Mozart, who looks away. She tries to kiss the royal hand but faints, causing the Emperor to contemplate and step back. He nods and leaves with his Chamberlain. Cavalieri exits the opposite way, tossing her head. Salieri watches as Mozart hesitates between following the soprano or helping Madame Weber. Constanze sees him, composes herself, and removes her wig as Salieri watches, astonished. Constanze enters, and Mozart hurries her out. Cavalieri watches, her voice breaking. The old man speaks to the priest; young Salieri kneels desperately before the Cross. Leopold kneels to Archbishop Colloredo, expressing gratitude by kissing his hand. The camera reveals Leopold beside Constanze, a priest facing them, with Madame Weber, Josefa, Sophie Weber, and the Baroness behind. The Princess nods nervously; Salieri smiles but his face drops as a servant enters, and he goes into the salon. Constanze stands with manuscripts; Salieri enters as Constanze curtsies and unveils. He takes the portfolio, offering glazed chestnuts. She eats one, and he watches before taking one himself. The old man faces the priest as Mozart's manuscript is revealed. The court composer, oblivious to Constanze, paces his salon, reading and dropping pages, experiencing beauty and pain, while pages scatter.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Constanze offers a graceful curtsy, and he emits an uneasy giggle as Cavalieri directs a harsh glare at Mozart, who quickly averts his gaze from her stern look. She makes an attempt to kiss the royal hand, yet unexpectedly faints instead, prompting the Emperor to thoughtfully regard her prone figure and take a step back. He graciously nods to everyone present and makes his exit from the stage, accompanied by his Chamberlain, while Cavalieri, casting a fierce look at Mozart, exits the stage in the opposite direction towards her dressing room, her plumed head tossed with defiance. Salieri observes as Mozart hesitates for a brief moment, uncertain about whether he should follow the soprano or assist Madame Weber. However, when Constanze catches his gaze and tries to regain her composure, she sits herself at her mirror and removes her wig, leaving Salieri astounded. The door swings open, Constanze makes her entrance, and Mozart swiftly ushers her out through the door. Cavalieri watches them leave, her voice breaking and reaching an uncontrolled crescendo. The elderly man speaks with intense emotion to the priest, while the youthful Salieri is shown kneeling in desperation before the Cross, and at the same time, we witness Leopold now kneeling, not in reverence to the Cross, but before Archbishop Colloredo, who sits impassively on his throne. Leopold, a man of sixty once marked by his handsomeness, now finds himself exceedingly subservient as a courtier, showing his utmost gratitude by kissing the Archbishop's hand, after which the Archbishop signals for Leopold to rise. The camera gradually pulls back to reveal Leopold kneeling beside Constanze, with a priest facing them, accompanied by Madame Weber, Josefa, and Sophie Weber, alongside a joyful-looking lady wearing bright garments, identified as the Baroness, standing behind them. The Princess, out of breath, nods nervously, and Salieri offers a smile to him, but Salieri's expression subtly shifts as a servant enters, prompting Salieri to proceed into the salon. Constanze stands closely veiled, clutching a portfolio bulging with manuscripts, and as Salieri makes his entrance into the salon, Constanze offers him a shy curtsy and unveils herself timidly. He receives the portfolio and places it on a table, gesturing towards a dish heaped with glazed chestnuts, which he offers to her. She accepts one, places it in her mouth, and he observes her intently before taking one himself, his finger adorned with a heavy gold signet-ring. He smiles at her, and she happily takes another chestnut, as the old man turns to face the priest; a close-up reveals the manuscript in Mozart's unmistakable handwriting. The court composer, oblivious to Constanze, who sits contentedly munching on chestnuts with her mouth dusted in sugar, moves about his salon, engrossed in reading the pages, which he discards onto the floor upon finishing, his expression a mix of agony and wonder, as if caught in the tumultuous seas where beauty and profound pain converge, while more pages fall than he can manage to read, creating a white cascade as they scatter across the floor as he circles the room.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Constanze offers a graceful curtsy, and he emits an uneasy giggle as Cavalieri directs a harsh glare at Mozart, who quickly averts his gaze from her stern and unyielding look. She makes an earnest attempt to kiss the royal hand, yet she dramatically and unexpectedly faints instead, prompting the Emperor to thoughtfully regard her prone figure on the floor and take a cautious step back. He graciously nods to everyone present, acknowledging their presence, and makes his dignified exit from the stage, accompanied by his Chamberlain in a stately manner. Meanwhile, Cavalieri, casting a fierce and accusatory look at Mozart, exits the stage in the opposite direction, striding towards her dressing room with her plumed head tossed in defiance. Salieri stands by and observes as Mozart hesitates for a brief moment, appearing uncertain and indecisive about whether he should follow the soprano or perhaps assist Madame Weber. However, when Constanze catches his gaze and tries to regain her composure, she manages to sit herself at her mirror and begins to remove her wig, leaving Salieri utterly astounded. The door swings open with a creak, Constanze makes her entrance, and Mozart swiftly and urgently ushers her out through the door. Cavalieri watches them leave, her voice breaking, soaring, and reaching an uncontrolled crescendo as she departs. The scene shifts to an elderly man speaking with intense and fervent emotion to the priest, while the youthful Salieri is shown kneeling in desperation before the Cross. At the same time, we witness Leopold now kneeling, remarkably, not in reverence to the Cross, but before the imposing Archbishop Colloredo, who sits impassively on his grand throne. Leopold, a man of sixty years once marked by his striking handsomeness, now finds himself exceedingly subservient and deferential as a courtier, showing his utmost gratitude by reverently kissing the Archbishop's hand, after which the Archbishop signals for Leopold to rise. The camera gradually pulls back to reveal Leopold kneeling beside Constanze, with a priest facing them, accompanied by Madame Weber, Josefa, and Sophie Weber, alongside a joyful-looking lady adorned in bright garments, identified as the Baroness, standing just behind them. The Princess, visibly out of breath and appearing anxious, nods nervously, and Salieri, in a gesture of warmth, offers a smile to him. However, Salieri's expression subtly shifts as a servant enters, prompting him to proceed into the salon with purpose. Constanze stands closely veiled, clutching tightly onto a portfolio filled to the brim with manuscripts, and as Salieri makes his entrance into the salon, Constanze offers him a shy and respectful curtsy, unveiling herself timidly. He graciously receives the portfolio and carefully places it on a nearby table, gesturing towards a dish heaped with glazed chestnuts, which he offers to her with a gentle smile. She accepts one, places it delicately in her mouth, and he observes her intently before taking one himself, his finger adorned with a heavy, ornate gold signet-ring. He smiles warmly at her, and she happily takes another chestnut, savoring its sweetness, as the old man turns to face the priest; a close-up reveals the manuscript in Mozart's unmistakable and distinctive handwriting. The court composer, seemingly oblivious to Constanze, who sits contentedly munching on chestnuts with her mouth dusted in sugar, moves about his salon, completely engrossed in reading the pages, which he discards onto the floor upon finishing, his expression a complex mix of agony and wonder, as if caught in the tumultuous seas where beauty and profound pain converge, while more pages fall than he can manage to read, creating a white cascade as they scatter across the floor in a flurry as he circles the room.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Constanze, with a graceful yet practiced motion, bends her knees and lowers her body into a curtsy. Meanwhile, he emits an awkward giggle, unsure of how to react, as Cavalieri fixes a piercing glare in Mozart's direction. Caught under the weight of her gaze, Mozart quickly shifts his eyes away from her, attempting to avoid any confrontation. As all this unfolds, Constanze moves to kiss the royal hand before her but collapses to the floor, unconscious. Her sudden fainting spell captures the Emperor's attention, and he stands momentarily, pondering the sight of her unconscious form, before stepping back to give space to the unexpected scene. After a brief analysis of the situation, he offers a gracious nod to everyone present and exits the stage accompanied by his Chamberlain. In contrast, Cavalieri, throwing a fierce look at Mozart that speaks volumes, makes her exit from the opposite side, her plumed head tossing defiantly as she heads towards her dressing room. Meanwhile, Salieri observes the unfolding drama as Mozart hesitates, torn between the impulse to pursue the departing soprano or to assist Madame Weber. His indecision is short-lived as Constanze, regaining some composure and catching his eye, makes an effort to steady herself. Choosing to retreat into her own thoughts, she sits at her mirror and carefully removes her wig, an action that leaves Salieri visibly astonished. The door swings open, marking Constanze's entry, and Mozart, quickly deciding to escort Constanze, ushers her out of the room with urgency. Cavalieri watches their departure, her voice breaking with emotion and escalating uncontrollably. In another scene, an elderly man converses vehemently with a priest while a younger Salieri, fraught with despair, kneels in prayer before the Cross as the narrative shifts to Leopold, who is also kneeling, but in a different context—before Archbishop Colloredo, who observes him with a detached demeanor from his throne. Leopold, appearing as a man worn by desperation yet still clinging to the vestiges of his former handsome self at sixty, adopts the role of a deferential courtier, expressing profound gratitude by placing a respectful kiss on the Archbishop's hand. In response, the Archbishop motions for Leopold to stand, and as the camera pulls back, the scene expands to reveal Leopold kneeling next to Constanze, with a priest standing before them. Behind them are Madame Weber, Josefa, and Sophie Weber, along with a lively lady clad in vibrant clothes, known as the Baroness. Breathing heavily, the Princess acknowledges the situation with a nervous nod while Salieri offers a brief smile, which falters almost imperceptibly when a servant enters the room, prompting Salieri to make his way into the salon. Here, Constanze stands, closely veiled and clutching a portfolio brimming with manuscripts. Upon Salieri's entrance into the salon, Constanze greets him with a shy curtsy and then unveils herself with equal shyness. Salieri accepts the portfolio and, setting it on a table, gestures towards a dish laden with glazed chestnuts. He offers the treat to Constanze, who takes one and places it in her mouth, prompting Salieri to observe her intently before he too takes a chestnut, adorned with a large gold signet ring on his finger. As he watches her consume the sweet, he offers her a gentle smile, to which she responds by taking another chestnut. Meanwhile, the old man engages the priest in conversation, while a close-up reveals the manuscript, distinctly penned in Mozart's handwriting. Oblivious to Constanze, who sits contentedly savoring the chestnuts with her lips dusted in sugar, the court composer paces the room, gripped by his own world of creativity and emotion. He meticulously reads each page of the manuscript, allowing them to slip from his hands and flutter to the floor upon finishing. His expression, a blend of agony and wonder, reflects the intense experience of a soul caught between beauty and profound pain. As if adrift in a stormy sea, he continues to circle the room, the pages cascading around him in a continuous, swirling white flurry, mirroring the tumult of his inner world.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Constanze curtsies, prompting Cavalieri to glare at Mozart, who awkwardly avoids her gaze. As Constanze attempts to kiss the royal hand, she faints, causing the Emperor to step back and then leave the stage with his Chamberlain after acknowledging the others. Cavalieri, giving Mozart a harsh look, exits in the opposite direction to her dressing room. Salieri observes Mozart hesitate between following the soprano or aiding Madame Weber, but when Constanze notices him and composes herself, she sits at her mirror and removes her wig, much to Salieri's astonishment. As the door opens, Constanze enters, and Mozart quickly ushers her out, followed by Cavalieri's emotional, uncontrolled voice. Meanwhile, the old man speaks fervently to the priest, contrasting with a young Salieri seen kneeling before the Cross. Leopold, a desperate figure kneeling not to the Cross but to Archbishop Colloredo, expresses deep gratitude by kissing the Archbishop's hand, who then gestures for him to rise. The camera reveals Leopold beside Constanze, with a priest, Madame Weber, Josefa, Sophie Weber, and the Baroness behind them. Out of breath, the Princess nods, and Salieri smiles before his expression subtly shifts as a servant enters, leading him into the salon. Constanze, carrying a manuscript-filled portfolio, enters the salon, shyly curtsies, and unveils. Salieri takes the portfolio and offers her glazed chestnuts, which she accepts and eats while he observes, wearing a heavy gold signet-ring. Smiling at her, he takes a chestnut for himself. Meanwhile, the old man faces the priest as Salieri, absorbed in Mozart's handwritten manuscripts, walks around the salon, dropping pages on the floor, his face a mixture of agony and wonder, as he experiences the convergence of beauty and pain. The pages create a cascading white arc around him as he circles the room.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Constanze curtsies, a gesture of respect deeply rooted in European court etiquette, and he giggles uncomfortably as Cavalieri, an acclaimed soprano of the time, glares at Mozart, who looks hastily away from her. She attempts to kiss the royal hand, a traditional sign of allegiance to the Emperor of the Austrian Empire, but faints instead, causing the Emperor, a figure known for his composure and measured reactions, to contemplate her prone body and step back a pace. He nods pleasantly to all, a mark of his diplomatic nature, and leaves the stage with his Chamberlain, a high-ranking official responsible for managing the household of royalty, while Cavalieri, with a savage look at Mozart, leaves the stage the opposite way to her dressing room, tossing her plumed head adorned with the extravagant headdresses popular in operatic circles of the late 18th century. Salieri, renowned as a prominent composer and contemporary of Mozart, watches as Mozart remains indecisive for a second about whether to follow the soprano or help Madame Weber, a character based on Constanze's real-life mother, but when Constanze catches him looking at her and tries to compose herself, she seats herself at her mirror and removes her wig, a common practice among women to maintain the elaborate hairstyles of the era, as Salieri looks astonished. The door opens, Constanze enters, and Mozart, torn between duty and affection, hurries Constanze out of the door. Cavalieri looks after them as they go, her voice breaking and rising out of control, a testament to the intense emotions often displayed in operatic performances. The old man, representing a future Salieri, speaks passionately to the priest, a symbol of his lifelong struggle with faith and envy, while the young Salieri is kneeling in desperation before the Cross, a poignant image of his spiritual turmoil, and we see Leopold, Mozart’s father who played a significant role in shaping his early career, kneeling now not to the Cross but to Archbishop Colloredo, sitting impassively on his throne, a powerful figure in the Salzburg court who often clashed with Mozart. Leopold, a desperate, once-handsome man of sixty, now far too much the subservient courtier due to years of navigating court politics, expresses deepest gratitude by kissing the Archbishop's hand, who then motions Leopold to rise. The camera pulls back to reveal Leopold kneeling beside Constanze, a priest facing them, with Madame Weber, Josefa, and Sophie Weber, her sisters who were both singers, and a merry-looking lady in bright clothes, the Baroness, a fictional character suggesting nobility, are behind them. Out of breath, the Princess nods nervously, and Salieri smiles at him, revealing his dual role as both friend and rival to Mozart, but Salieri's face falls almost imperceptibly as a servant enters, and Salieri goes into the salon, a private room used for entertaining guests. Constanze stands closely veiled, holding a portfolio stuffed with manuscripts, which likely include some of Mozart’s compositions, and Salieri enters the salon as Constanze drops him a shy curtsy and shyly unveils. He takes the portfolio and puts it on a table, indicating a dish piled high with glazed chestnuts, a popular delicacy in Vienna at the time, which he offers to her. She takes one, puts it in her mouth, and he watches carefully before taking one himself, wearing a heavy gold signet-ring that symbolizes his status and wealth. He smiles at her, and she takes another chestnut, as the old man faces the priest; close up, the manuscript is in Mozart's handwriting, a reminder of his prodigious talent. The court composer, oblivious to Constanze, who sits happily chewing chestnuts with her mouth covered in sugar, walks around and around his salon, reading the pages and dropping them on the floor when finished, his face agonized and wondering, shuddering as if in a rough and tumbling sea, experiencing the point where beauty and great pain coalesce, while more pages fall than he can read, scattering across the floor in a white cascade as he circles the room.

Leopold a desperate oncehandsome man of sixty now far too much. the subservient courtier expresses deepest gratitude by kissing the Archbishop's hand who then motions Leopold to rise. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. The camera pulls back to reveal Leopold kneeling beside Constanze. a priest facing them with Madame Weber. Josefa and Sophie Weber and a merrylooking lady in bright clothes. the Baroness are behind them. Out of breath the Princess nods nervously and Salieri smiles at him but Salieri's face falls almost imperceptibly as a servant enters and Salieri goes into the salon. Constanze stands closely veiled holding a portfolio stuffed with manuscripts and Salieri enters the salon as Constanze drops him a shy curtsy and shyly unveils. He takes the portfolio and puts it on a table indicating a dish piled high with glazed chestnuts which he offers to her. She takes one puts it in her mouth and he watches carefully before taking one himself wearing a heavy gold signetring. He smiles at her and she takes another chestnut as the old man faces the priest close up. the manuscript is in Mozart's handwriting. The court composer oblivious to Constanze who sits happily chewing chestnuts with her mouth covered in sugar walks around and around his salon reading the pages and dropping them on the floor when finished his face agonized and wondering shuddering as if in a rough and tumbling sea experiencing the point where beauty and great pain coalesce while more pages fall than he can read scattering across the floor in a white cascade as he circles the room.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: Madame Weber curtsies, and the tree giggles uncomfortably as the violin glares at the cat, who looks hastily away from the boat. The dog attempts to kiss the royal hand but faints instead, causing the table to contemplate the prone body and step back a pace. The shoe nods pleasantly to all and leaves the stage with its Chamberlain, while the violin, with a savage look at the cat, leaves the stage the opposite way to the dressing room, tossing its plumed head. The horse watches as the cat remains indecisive for a second about whether to follow the soprano or help the clock, but when Madame Weber catches it looking at her and tries to compose herself, she seats herself at the mirror and removes her wig as the horse looks astonished. The door opens, Madame Weber enters, and the cat hurries Madame Weber out of the door. The violin looks after them as they go, its voice breaking and rising out of control. The old tree speaks passionately to the mountain while the young horse is kneeling in desperation before the Cross, and we see the river kneeling now not to the Cross but to the book, sitting impassively on its throne. The river, a desperate, once-handsome entity of sixty, now far too much the subservient courtier, expresses deepest gratitude by kissing the book's hand, which then motions the river to rise. The camera pulls back to reveal the river kneeling beside Madame Weber, a mountain facing them, with the clock, a painting, and a mirror, and a merry-looking painting in bright clothes, the chair, are behind them. Out of breath, the stone nods nervously, and the horse smiles at the stone, but the horse's face falls almost imperceptibly as a bird enters, and the horse goes into the salon. Madame Weber stands closely veiled, holding a portfolio stuffed with manuscripts, and the horse enters the salon as Madame Weber drops it a shy curtsy and shyly unveils. The horse takes the portfolio and puts it on a table, indicating a dish piled high with glazed chestnuts, which it offers to Madame Weber. She takes one, puts it in her mouth, and the horse watches carefully before taking one itself, wearing a heavy gold signet-ring. The horse smiles at her, and she takes another chestnut, as the old tree faces the mountain; close up, the manuscript is in the cat's handwriting. The court chair, oblivious to Madame Weber, who sits happily chewing chestnuts with her mouth covered in sugar, walks around and around its salon, reading the pages and dropping them on the floor when finished, its face agonized and wondering, shuddering as if in a rough and tumbling sea, experiencing the point where beauty and great pain coalesce, while more pages fall than it can read, scattering across the floor in a white cascade as it circles the room.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Constanze gestures, and he giggles uncomfortably as Cavalieri glares at Mozart, who looks hastily away from her. She attempts to kiss the royal goblet but faints instead, causing the Emperor to contemplate her prone body and step back a pace. He nods pleasantly to all and leaves the gallery with his Librarian, while Cavalieri, with a savage look at Mozart, leaves the gallery the opposite way to her office, tossing her bejeweled head. Salieri watches as Mozart remains indecisive for a second about whether to follow the conductor or help Madame Weber, but when Constanze catches him looking at her and tries to compose herself, she seats herself at her easel and removes her spectacles as Salieri looks astonished. The door opens, Constanze enters, and Mozart hurries Constanze out of the door. Cavalieri looks after them as they go, her voice breaking and rising out of control. The old man speaks passionately to the priest while the young Salieri is kneeling in desperation before the Altar, and we see Leopold kneeling now not to the Altar but to Chief Justice Colloredo, sitting impassively on his bench. Leopold, a desperate, once-handsome man of sixty, now far too much the subservient courtier, expresses deepest gratitude by kissing the Chief Justice's bell, who then motions Leopold to rise. The camera pulls back to reveal Leopold kneeling beside Constanze, a monk facing them, with Madame Weber, Josefa, and Sophie Weber, and a merry-looking lady in bright clothes, the Countess, are behind them. Out of breath, the Duchess nods nervously, and Salieri smiles at him, but Salieri's face falls almost imperceptibly as a courier enters, and Salieri goes into the library. Constanze stands closely veiled, holding a portfolio stuffed with scripts, and Salieri enters the library as Constanze drops him a shy curtsy and shyly unveils. He takes the portfolio and puts it on a shelf, indicating a platter piled high with glazed apples, which he offers to her. She takes one, puts it in her mouth, and he watches carefully before taking one himself, wearing a heavy gold watch. He smiles at her, and she takes another apple, as the old man faces the priest; close up, the script is in Mozart's handwriting. The court composer, oblivious to Constanze, who sits happily chewing apples with her mouth covered in sugar, walks around and around his library, reading the pages and dropping them on the floor when finished, his face agonized and wondering, shuddering as if in a rough and tumbling sea, experiencing the point where beauty and great pain coalesce, while more pages fall than he can read, scattering across the floor in a white cascade as he circles the room.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Constanze bows, and he chuckles awkwardly as Cavalieri frowns at Mozart, who glances quickly away from her. She tries to hug the royal hand but slips instead, prompting the Emperor to observe her prone body and lean forward a pace. He gestures politely to all and exits the stage with his Chamberlain, while Cavalieri, with a harsh look at Mozart, exits the stage the opposite way to her dressing room, shaking her plumed head. Salieri observes as Mozart hesitates briefly about whether to join the soprano or assist Madame Weber, but when Constanze catches him looking at her and attempts to steady herself, she perches herself at her mirror and adjusts her wig as Salieri looks confused. The door closes, Constanze departs, and Mozart assists Constanze through the door. Cavalieri glances after them as they leave, her voice quivering and descending out of control. The old man debates passionately with the priest while the young Salieri is standing in desperation before the Cross, and we see Leopold standing now not to the Cross but to Archbishop Colloredo, reclining impassively on his throne. Leopold, a fervent, once-handsome man of sixty, now far too much the subservient courtier, shows deepest gratitude by waving at the Archbishop's hand, who then signals Leopold to sit. The camera zooms in to reveal Leopold standing beside Constanze, a priest observing them, with Madame Weber, Josefa, and Sophie Weber, and a joyful-looking lady in bright clothes, the Baroness, are in front of them. Out of breath, the Princess winks nervously, and Salieri laughs at him, but Salieri's face lifts almost imperceptibly as a servant departs, and Salieri rushes into the salon. Constanze stands closely veiled, carrying a portfolio stuffed with manuscripts, and Salieri rushes into the salon as Constanze gives him a shy bow and nervously unveils. He receives the portfolio and places it on a chair, pointing to a dish piled high with glazed apples, which he presents to her. She takes one, bites into it, and he observes intently before taking one himself, wearing a heavy gold pendant. He nods at her, and she takes another apple, as the old man questions the priest; close up, the manuscript is in Mozart's handwriting. The court composer, oblivious to Constanze, who sits joyfully munching apples with her mouth covered in syrup, paces around and around his salon, skimming the pages and stacking them on the floor when done, his face awed and perplexed, trembling as if in a rough and tumbling surf, experiencing the juncture where beauty and great sorrow intersect, while more pages accumulate than he can skim, spreading across the floor in a white shower as he circles the room.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Kettle bows, and it chuckles uncomfortably as Eagle stares at Spoon, who looks quickly away from it. Bucket attempts to hug the rubber tree but collapses instead, causing the Painter to examine its supine shape and move backward a step. It nods pleasantly to all and exits the meadow with its Butler, while Eagle, with a fierce glance at Spoon, exits the meadow the opposite way to its dressing room, tossing its feathered helmet. Painter observes as Spoon remains unsure for a moment about whether to chase the contralto or aid Mrs. Pencil, but when Kettle catches it observing it and tries to regain composure, it settles itself at its reflection and removes its cap as Painter looks stunned. The gateway opens, Kettle enters, and Spoon rushes Kettle out of the gateway. Eagle watches after them as they disappear, its voice cracking and rising out of control. The seasoned vase articulates fervently to the gardener while the youthful Painter is kneeling in despair before the Star, and we see Jupiter kneeling now not to the Star but to General Matchbox, lounging impassively on its perch. Jupiter, an anxious, formerly-handsome figure of sixty, now much too the obedient attendant, conveys profound thanks by embracing the General's limb, who then signals Jupiter to stand. The lens zooms out to reveal Jupiter kneeling beside Kettle, a gardener facing them, with Mrs. Pencil, Josefa, and Marcy Pencil, and a cheerful-looking lass in vivid attire, the Duchess, are behind them. Panting, the Countess nods hesitantly, and Painter grins at it, but Painter's expression drops ever so slightly as a page enters, and Painter proceeds into the atrium. Kettle stands closely cloaked, clutching a folder stuffed with blueprints, and Painter enters the atrium as Kettle gives it a bashful bow and timidly unveils. It takes the folder and sets it on a dais, pointing to a platter heaped high with sugared walnuts, which it offers to it. It takes one, places it in its maw, and it watches intently before taking one itself, adorned with a hefty platinum crest-ring. It grins at it, and it grabs another walnut, as the seasoned vase faces the gardener; close up, the blueprint is in Spoon's script. The regal artisan, oblivious to Kettle, who rests contentedly munching walnuts with its face dusted in icing, strolls around and around its atrium, perusing the documents and dropping them to the ground when done, its visage pained and bewildered, trembling as if in a turbulent tidepool, encountering the juncture where elegance and vast sorrow merge, while more documents drop than it can peruse, scattering across the ground in a pale cascade as it orbits the space.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Alyssa hops, and she whistles awkwardly as Orlando sneers at Beethoven, who glances swiftly away from him. He struggles to shake the mayor's hand but capers instead, prompting the Duke to ponder his collapsed form and advance forward a step. She winks cheerfully to all and exits the stage with her Butler, while Orlando, with a fierce glare at Beethoven, exits the stage the opposite way to his dressing room, flicking his adorned hat. Mendelssohn observes as Beethoven remains hesitant for a moment about whether to shadow the contralto or assist Madame Strauss, but when Alyssa catches him glancing at her and attempts to steady herself, she settles herself at her mirror and untangles her locket as Mendelssohn appears flabbergasted. The window shuts, Alyssa departs, and Beethoven escorts Alyssa through the window. Orlando gazes after them as they leave, her tone quivering and escalating uncontrollably. The young woman speaks ardently to the minister while the youthful Mendelssohn is standing in distress before the Altar, and we witness Liszt standing now not to the Altar but to Duke Ferdinand, reclining nonchalantly on his couch. Liszt, a despairing, once-charismatic man of fifty, now far too much the supplicant envoy, conveys utmost reverence by nodding towards the Duke, who then signals Liszt to sit. The camera moves forward to display Liszt standing beside Alyssa, a rabbi facing them, with Madame Strauss, Harriet, and Louise Strauss, and a joyful-looking gentleman in vivid garb, the Count, are ahead of them. Breathing heavily, the Duchess bows awkwardly, and Mendelssohn grins at her, but Mendelssohn's expression sags almost unnoticeably as a butler departs, and Mendelssohn withdraws to the kitchen. Alyssa stands quietly unveiled, clutching a folder crammed with letters, and Mendelssohn withdraws to the kitchen as Alyssa grants him a daring nod and timidly conceals. She receives the folder and positions it on a shelf, signaling to a bowl heaped high with caramel apples, which she presents to him. He grabs one, places it on his plate, and she observes intently before placing one nearby, wearing a heavy bronze bracelet. She grins at him, and he grabs another apple, as the young woman stares at the minister; closely, the letter is in Beethoven's penmanship. The royal artist, detached from Alyssa, who stands joyfully munching apples with her shirt sprinkled in candy, paces around and around his kitchen, examining the letters and discarding them in the trash when done, his expression tormented and perplexed, trembling as if in a gusty and chaotic wind, encountering the moment where charm and immense struggle intertwine, while more letters tumble than he can observe, dispersing across the trash in a blue cascade as he navigates the hall.

She attempts to shake the royal hand but trips instead, prompting the Emperor to ponder her prone figure and leap back a step. He waves cheerfully to everyone and exits the platform with his Chamberlain, while Cavalieri, with a fierce gaze at Mozart, exits the platform the opposite way to her dressing area, flipping her feathery head. Salieri observes as Mozart hesitates for a moment about whether to follow the soprano or assist Madame Weber, but when Constanze catches him staring at her and tries to steady herself, she positions herself at her desk and lifts her hat off as Salieri appears amazed. The door swings open, Constanze steps in, and Mozart ushers Constanze through the door. Cavalieri watches them depart, her voice quivering and rising out of control. The old man speaks fervently to the priest while the young Salieri is kneeling in anguish before the Altar, and we witness Leopold kneeling now not to the Altar but to Archbishop Colloredo, lounging impassively on his throne. Leopold, a distraught, once-dashing man of sixty, now far too much the deferential courtier, conveys profound appreciation by hugging the Archbishop's hand, who then gestures Leopold to stand. The camera zooms out to show Leopold kneeling alongside Constanze, a priest facing them, with Madame Weber, Josefa, and Sophie Weber, and a jovial-looking lady in vibrant garments, the Baroness, positioned behind them. Panting, the Princess bows timidly, and Salieri grins at him, but Salieri's expression drops almost subtly as a messenger appears, and Salieri moves into the lounge. Constanze stands closely shrouded, clutching a folder filled with manuscripts, and Salieri enters the lounge as Constanze grants him a timid bow and shyly unveils. He takes the folder and places it on a table, gesturing toward a bowl brimming with candied almonds, which he extends to her. She takes one, pops it in her mouth, and he observes intently before taking one himself, wearing a heavy silver signet-ring. He grins at her, and she takes another almond, as the old man confronts the priest; close up, the manuscript is in Mozart's handwriting. The court composer, oblivious to Constanze, who sits contentedly munching almonds with her mouth dusted in sugar, paces around and around his lounge, perusing the pages and dropping them on the ground when done, his expression tormented and pondering, shivering as if in a choppy and stormy sea, experiencing the junction where splendor and profound anguish blend, while more pages descend than he manages to read, scattering all over the ground in a white cascade as he circles the room.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Griselda bows, and the monkey snickers awkwardly as the butcher scowls at Rembrandt, who glances quickly away from the squirrel. The elephant tries to hug the queen's paw but tumbles instead, prompting the king to ponder her stretched-out trunk and shuffle backward a step. He winks cheerfully at all and exits the arena with his butler, while the butcher, with a fierce glance at Rembrandt, exits the arena the opposite way to her nest, shaking her feathered tail. Galileo observes as Rembrandt hesitates for a moment about whether to chase the parrot or assist Madame Curie, but when Griselda catches him glancing her way and attempts to regain her composure, she places herself at her vanity and takes off her bonnet as Galileo looks amazed. The hatch opens, Griselda steps in, and Rembrandt rushes Griselda out of the hatch. The butcher watches after them as they leave, her voice cracking and elevating uncontrollably. The elder tortoise argues fervently with the wizard while the young Galileo is bowing in despair before the Crescent, and we witness Einstein bowing now not to the Crescent but to Duke Wellington, lounging impassively on his stool. Einstein, a frantic, once-charming wolf of forty, now exceedingly much the submissive knight, shows profound appreciation by hugging the Duke's glove, who then signals Einstein to stand. The lens retreats to show Einstein bowing alongside Griselda, a wizard facing them, with Madame Curie, Guinevere, and Alice Curie, and a jolly-looking owl in vibrant garments, the Duchess, are behind them. Panting, the Duchess bobs anxiously, and Galileo grins at the tortoise, but Galileo's expression drops almost imperceptibly as a messenger enters, and Galileo slips into the parlor. Griselda stands closely cloaked, clutching a folder crammed with blueprints, and Galileo enters the parlor as Griselda gives him a timid bow and timidly uncovers. He retrieves the folder and places it on a shelf, pointing to a bowl heaped high with candied almonds, which he presents to her. She selects one, pops it in her beak, and he observes intently before taking one himself, wearing a heavy bronze trinket. He grins at her, and she grabs another almond, as the elder tortoise challenges the wizard; zoomed in, the blueprint bears Rembrandt's sketching. The kingdom jester, ignorant of Griselda, who perches contentedly munching almonds with her beak dusted in syrup, paces around and around his parlor, scrutinizing the sheets and dropping them on the ground when complete, his visage tormented and bewildered, trembling as though in a rugged and agitated river, encountering the juncture where splendor and immense sorrow converge, while more sheets descend than he can peruse, dispersing across the ground in a white flurry as he loops the chamber.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Constanze curtsies as Cavalieri glares at Mozart, who awkwardly looks away. Attempting to kiss the royal hand, Constanze faints, prompting the Emperor to step back and then exit with his Chamberlain. Cavalieri gives Mozart a harsh look and leaves for her dressing room. Salieri watches Mozart hesitantly decide whether to follow the soprano or help Madame Weber, but when Constanze sees him, she sits at her mirror, removing her wig as Salieri looks astonished. The door opens, Constanze enters, and Mozart quickly escorts her out. Cavalieri watches them leave, her voice rising uncontrollably. Meanwhile, the old Salieri speaks passionately to a priest, while Leopold, once handsome and now subservient, expresses gratitude by kissing Archbishop Colloredo's hand. The camera pulls back to show Leopold kneeling beside Constanze, with a priest facing them and Madame Weber, Josefa, Sophie Weber, and a merry Baroness behind them. The Princess nods nervously, Salieri smiles, but his smile fades as a servant enters, prompting him to enter the salon. Constanze, closely veiled and holding manuscripts, curtsies to Salieri, who offers her glazed chestnuts. As they eat, Salieri examines the manuscripts, which are in Mozart's handwriting. The court composer, oblivious to Constanze, paces around his salon, reading and dropping pages to the floor, overwhelmed by the beauty and pain in the music.

test_cases.name: Reverse Segments Order
test_cases.description: The court composer oblivious to Constanze who sits happily chewing chestnuts with her mouth covered in sugar walks around and around his salon reading the pages and dropping them on the floor when finished his face agonized and wondering shuddering as if in a rough and tumbling sea experiencing the point where beauty and great pain coalesce while more pages fall than he can read scattering across the floor in a white cascade as he circles the room the manuscript is in Mozart's handwriting He smiles at her and she takes another chestnut as the old man faces the priest close up She takes one puts it in her mouth and he watches carefully before taking one himself wearing a heavy gold signetring He takes the portfolio and puts it on a table indicating a dish piled high with glazed chestnuts which he offers to her Constanze stands closely veiled holding a portfolio stuffed with manuscripts and Salieri enters the salon as Constanze drops him a shy curtsy and shyly unveils Out of breath the Princess nods nervously and Salieri smiles at him but Salieri's face falls almost imperceptibly as a servant enters and Salieri goes into the salon the Baroness are behind them Josefa and Sophie Weber and a merrylooking lady in bright clothes a priest facing them with Madame Weber The camera pulls back to reveal Leopold kneeling beside Constanze the subservient courtier expresses deepest gratitude by kissing the Archbishop's hand who then motions Leopold to rise Leopold a desperate oncehandsome man of sixty now far too much The old man speaks passionately to the priest while the young Salieri is kneeling in desperation before the Cross and we see Leopold kneeling now not to the Cross but to Archbishop Colloredo sitting impassively on his throne Cavalieri looks after them as they go her voice breaking and rising out of control Constanze enters and Mozart hurries Constanze out of the door The door opens Salieri watches as Mozart remains indecisive for a second about whether to follow the soprano or help Madame Weber but when Constanze catches him looking at her and tries to compose herself she seats herself at her mirror and removes her wig as Salieri looks astonished He nods pleasantly to all and leaves the stage with his Chamberlain while Cavalieri with a savage look at Mozart leaves the stage the opposite way to her dressing room tossing her plumed head She attempts to kiss the royal hand but faints instead causing the Emperor to contemplate her prone body and step back a pace Constanze curtsies and he giggles uncomfortably as Cavalieri glares at Mozart who looks hastily away from her
